resources.string: # TESA Scenario Game: Power Plant Park Analysis

This virtual energy system laboratory is implemented to simulate the energy market's behavior. By varying the different parameters, you will be able to analyze the market's reactions on political decisions and changes of economical and ecological parameters.
The simulation model can be used in two ways:
1. Use of the program without the necessity of programming skills: the energy system's reactions on parameter variations can be analyzed.
2. Analysis/change of the source code: to understand the code behind the optimization model, you can refere to the downloadable python scripts.
The solver is able to consider diverse parameters for the simulation. You can set the following parameters manually to analyze the energy system under the conditions you specified.

The energy market is not only dominated by technical influences or legal requirements. Main factors for investment decisions economic ones. Revenues and expenses are discounted using interest rates. The so called annuity discount factor $ADF$, which is necessary to calculate capital values, can be calculated by using the following formula (where $T$ stands for the plant type's lifetime and $i$ represents the interest rate):
By applying the following formula the **capital value $\kappa$** can be determined:
Alternatively, it is also possible to determine the **discounted costs per year $c$ (annuity)**:
* *$j=1...T$*: Year of time period in a
* *$n$*: Lifetime of a powerplant in a

Below, some parameters of the different plant types can be specified. These parameters comprise the efficiency, the lifetime, and the specific investment costs. After setting the parameters to values of your choice, you can see a summary of all parameters by clicking on the next button:
If you want to return to standard values, you can click the following button. By clicking this button the changes of the plant parameters will be reset.
If you want to return to standard values, you can click the following button. By clicking this button the changes of the plant parameters will be reset.
Next, you have to decide, if any restrictions for CO2 emissions are to be considered by the model. Choose one of the following options:
For this option each emitted ton of CO2 costs a fixed value. Please specify this value in the following:

For this option only a specified quantity of CO2 can be emitted. The reference value is here the amount of CO2 emissions of Germany in the year 1990 (ca. 1000Mt), which is also taken into account for the valuation of the climate targets. You can specify the percentage, which can be emitted in your model:

In 2011, Germany decided to phase-out nuclear power plants until the year 2023. By ticking the next box you can implement this decision and prevent nuclear power plants from beeing installed within the model.
There exists an ongoing debate about a possible coal phase-out in Germany. If you want to analyze effects of such a phase-out, please tick the follwing boxes:
To analyse effects of renewable power plants like solar PV and wind energy, you can choose to inlcude them in the model. In order to to consider PV and wind energy, you can tick the following box:
You can also set a minimum capacity of renewable energies. If you tick the next box, you will set a minimum of 10GW for the installed capacity of wind and solar PV.

Further, it is possible to analyze the energy system for different time horizons. There is the option to analyze the market for a different amount of time steps. The more time steps per year are taken into account, the more precise the results get. However, it has to be mentioned that the required computational power increases, too. In the following, you can specify the number of time steps per year and the number of years, which shall be analyzed:
Once all parameter values are chosen, you can start the simulation process by clicking the red "Run!" button. The model's output will is visualized and summarized below.
Below you find the resutls charts for analyzing the results:
You can download your results from the following link:
